study.title: Prevalence of methicillin resistant staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) among isolates from surgical site infections in Mulago hospital-Kampala, Uganda
study.journal: The Internet Journal of Infectious Diseases

design.inclusion_criteria_text: All patients (n = 188) who underwent elective and emergency surgery during the study period and developed SSI after surgery as defined by Centers for Disease Control and Prevention criteria.

eligibility.population: Patients who underwent elective and emergency surgery and developed surgical site infection (SSI) as defined by CDC criteria.

populations.description: All patients with SSI after elective and emergency surgery at Mulago Hospital during study period

provenance.text_snippet: All patients (n = 188) who underwent elective and emergency surgery during the study period were enrolled.

definitions.resistance_definition_text: MRSA defined by oxacillin agar screen and confirmed by PCR detection of mecA gene.
definitions.outcome_definitions_text: MRSA prevalence among S. aureus isolates from SSI.

lab_methods.specimen_collection_method: Sterile dry cotton swabs with Amies transport media collected from active part of infected surgical wounds or pus discharge.
lab_methods.culture_method: Swabs inoculated on phenol red mannitol salt agar, incubated at 37Â°C for 24 hrs; S. aureus identified by colony morphology, Gram stain, catalase, DNase, coagulase tests, and sub-cultured on 5% blood agar.
lab_methods.QC_measures: S. aureus ATCC 29213 (oxacillin susceptible) and ATCC 43300 (oxacillin resistant) used as control strains for both oxacillin agar screen and PCR.
lab_methods.organism_identification_method: Biochemical tests (colony morphology, Gram stain, catalase, DNase, coagulase), PCR for mecA gene.

amr_proportions.ast_method: oxacillin agar screen, PCR for mecA
amr_proportions.notes: MRSA defined by PCR detection of mecA gene.

provenance.text_snippet: Seventeen (31.5%) of the 54 isolates were confirmed as MRSA by PCR.

codes.subtheme: resistance patterns and rates by pathogen/antibiotic
codes.summary: MRSA is highly prevalent (31.5%) among S. aureus isolates from surgical site infections in Mulago Hospital, Uganda.

evidence_quotes.quote: Seventeen (31.5%) of the 54 isolates were confirmed as MRSA by PCR.
MRSA is highly (31.5%) prevalent among populations of S. aureus isolated from surgical site infections in Mulago National Referral Hospital, Kampala Uganda.

codes.location_context: Mulago National Referral Hospital, Kampala, Uganda

provenance.text_snippet: Seventeen (31.5%) of the 54 isolates were confirmed as MRSA by PCR.

codes.summary: Staphylococcus aureus is highly prevalent (28.7%) in surgical site infections in Mulago Hospital, Uganda.

evidence_quotes.quote: Out of the 188 specimen cultured, 54 (28.7%) grew S. aureus.
S. aureus is highly (28.7%) prevalent in surgical site infections in Mulago National Referral Hospital, Kampala Uganda.

codes.location_context: Mulago National Referral Hospital, Kampala, Uganda

provenance.text_snippet: Out of the 188 specimen cultured, 54 (28.7%) grew S. aureus.

codes.subtheme: determinants (inappropriate use, IPC gaps, diagnostics delays, policy failures, supply chain, workforce, patient factors)
codes.summary: Indiscriminate use of antibiotics may explain the observed MRSA prevalence in SSI at Mulago Hospital.

evidence_quotes.quote: Emergence of documented multi-drug resistance bacteria pathogens (Agwu et al., 2004) due to indiscriminate use of antibiotics (Agwu et al., 2005) may explain the observed 31.5% prevalence of MRSA in SSI at the Mulago National Referral Hospital Kampala, Uganda.

codes.location_context: Mulago National Referral Hospital, Kampala, Uganda

provenance.text_snippet: Emergence of documented multi-drug resistance bacteria pathogens (Agwu et al., 2004) due to indiscriminate use of antibiotics (Agwu et al., 2005) may explain the observed 31.5% prevalence of MRSA in SSI at the Mulago National Referral Hospital Kampala, Uganda.

notes_flags.detail: No SSI incidence (events/denominator) reported; only S. aureus isolation rate among SSI patients.

provenance.text_snippet: Out of the 188 specimen cultured, 54 (28.7%) grew S. aureus.

notes_flags.detail: No clinical outcomes (morbidity, mortality, reoperation, readmission, LOS, costs) reported.

provenance.text_snippet: Results Out of the 188 specimen cultured, 54 (28.7%) grew S. aureus. Seventeen (31.5%) of the 54 isolates were confirmed as MRSA by PCR.

notes_flags.detail: No stewardship guidelines, interventions, or policy capacity data reported.

provenance.text_snippet: The objective of this study was to determine the prevalence of MRSA among S. aureus isolates from surgical site infections in Mulago Hospital, Kampala, Uganda.
This was done on a patient who developed SSI after surgery as defined by Centers for Disease Control and Prevention criteria ( Horan et al, 1992).

provenance_index.text_snippet: Seventeen (31.5%) of the 54 isolates were confirmed as MRSA by PCR.
Out of the 188 specimen cultured, 54 (28.7%) grew S. aureus.
All patients (n = 188) who underwent elective and emergency surgery during the study period were enrolled.

Emergence of documented multi-drug resistance bacteria pathogens (Agwu et al., 2004) due to indiscriminate use of antibiotics (Agwu et al., 2005) may explain the observed 31.5% prevalence of MRSA in SSI at the Mulago National Referral Hospital Kampala, Uganda.
MRSA is highly (31.5%) prevalent among populations of S. aureus isolated from surgical site infections in Mulago National Referral Hospital, Kampala Uganda.

missing_fields: clinical outcomes (morbidity, mortality, reoperation, readmission, LOS, costs)
parser_warnings: No SSI incidence (events/denominator) reported; only S. aureus isolation rate among SSI patients.
No stewardship, intervention, or policy capacity data.
